Award.AbstractNarration:
The present project will study electron-molecule collision processes in gas phase, on surfaces, in cluster environment and in the presence of strong laser fields. A particular focus will be on biologically-relevant molecules, like simple amino acids, for which basic electron attachment mechanisms will be investigated. The effects of laser fields in electron-molecule interaction will also be studied.

This research will create new knowledge in the areas connecting collision physics with chemical control, radiobiology and atmospheric science. The research will involve interdisciplinary efforts and collaborations with scientists from other fields. It will train students in broader areas, including several subdisciplines. Examples demonstrating the role of low-energy electrons in different areas of chemistry, biology and environmental science will be incorporated in teaching.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit::

New physical mechanisms in the processes of electron-impact bond breaking in molecules were found. A significant progress in resolving a long-standing controversy in the problem of low-energy electron interaction with halogen molecules has been made. The effects of molecular clusters, which are many molecules loosely bound by weak forces, in the processes of electron attachment to molecules with a subsequent bond breaking were studied and were found to be significant. These findings has improved our knowledge about electron interactions with molecules and clusters and mechanisms for molecular bond breaking. New theoretical tools for investigation of ionization of molecules have been developed. Their application allowed a better understanding of the dynamics of molecular ionization by strong laser fields

 

Broader impacts:

The findings have contributed to the field of the radiation biodamage and ion-beam cancer therapy. First, the results for electron attachment to amino acids show how low-energy electrons can produce the bond breaking in these molecules. Second, the results on surface and cluster effects show how the bond breaking process in biomolecules is affected by surface and cluster environments. These findings are also important for atmospheric science as electron attachment processes in stratospheric clouds typically occur on surfaces of ice particles. 

The present project provided opportunities for training and mentoring of two postdoctoral research associates. Both were trained in research and scientific writing, and one was trained in teaching.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/28/2014
Modified by: Ilya I Fabrikant
